title: Kitchen Burns Prevention
legalBasis: Law 31/1995 on Occupational Risk Prevention; Royal Decree 486/1997 on workplace conditions; Royal Decree 773/1997 on personal protective equipment; Royal Decree 1215/1997 on work equipment safety
summary:
Burns are one of the most frequent and potentially serious injuries in commercial kitchens. Hospitality workers face constant exposure to multiple burn hazards including hot cooking surfaces and equipment, boiling liquids and steam, hot oil for frying, flame from gas burners, hot oven interiors and baking equipment, and heated serving containers. Burns range from minor first-degree burns causing temporary pain and redness to severe third-degree burns requiring extensive medical treatment, skin grafts, prolonged sick leave, and potentially permanent scarring or disability. Beyond the immediate pain and injury, serious burns carry infection risk and can result in psychological trauma.

Burn prevention in professional kitchens requires comprehensive measures addressing equipment design and maintenance, personal protective equipment provision, safe work procedures and training, kitchen layout and workflow organization, and cultivation of a safety-conscious culture. Spanish occupational health law requires employers to assess burn risks, implement control measures, provide appropriate protective equipment, train workers in safe practices, and establish emergency response procedures. Workers have corresponding duties to follow safety procedures, use provided protective equipment, report unsafe conditions, and exercise reasonable care.

Many kitchen burns are entirely preventable through proper precautions. Common scenarios leading to burns include reaching across hot surfaces to access items on the other side, failing to use appropriate heat-protective gloves or mitts when handling hot items, inadequate communication in shared kitchen spaces leading to collisions while carrying hot liquids, improper technique when opening lids or containers releasing steam, splashing or spilling of hot oil during frying operations, and contact with hot equipment due to poor equipment placement or inadequate guards. Understanding these common scenarios and the preventive measures for each dramatically reduces burn injury risk.

This guide addresses burn prevention for all kitchen workers, from apprentices to experienced chefs. Regardless of experience level, burns can occur in moments of inattention, during high-pressure service periods, or when safety procedures are bypassed. Maintaining consistent burn prevention practices, even under time pressure, is essential for career-long safety in hospitality kitchens.
keyPoints: Use heat-resistant gloves or mitts when handling any hot cookware, equipment, or containers
Announce when carrying hot items through kitchen: 'hot behind,' 'caliente,' or similar clear warning
Turn pot and pan handles inward on stovetops so they cannot be bumped or caught on clothing
Open lids away from you to allow steam to escape without scalding your face or arms
Assume all kitchen equipment is hot unless you know otherwise — never touch surfaces without verification
Wear appropriate clothing: long sleeves protect arms, no loose or synthetic fabrics that can melt
Maintain safe distance from open flames and hot oil operations
Know the location of the first aid kit and burn treatment supplies including cool running water
Report all burn injuries immediately to supervisor and seek appropriate first aid or medical attention
Employers must provide heat-protective PPE, maintain equipment safely, and train workers in burn prevention

sections.heading: 1. Types of Kitchen Burns and Their Hazards
sections.content:
Burns are classified by severity into three degrees. First-degree burns affect only the outer layer of skin (epidermis), causing redness, pain, and minor swelling, similar to a mild sunburn. These typically heal within days without scarring. Second-degree burns extend into the deeper layer of skin (dermis), causing intense pain, significant swelling, blistering, and weeping. Healing takes weeks and may leave scarring depending on depth. Third-degree burns destroy the full thickness of skin and may extend into underlying fat, muscle, or bone. Paradoxically, severe third-degree burns may be less painful initially because nerve endings are destroyed, but they require immediate medical attention and extensive treatment including skin grafts. Even small third-degree burns are medical emergencies.

Kitchen workers face several distinct burn hazard types. Contact burns occur when skin touches hot surfaces — stovetops, oven racks, baking trays, pot handles, grill surfaces, or heated equipment exteriors. Scald burns result from contact with hot liquids (boiling water, stocks, sauces) or steam, which carries tremendous heat energy and can penetrate clothing causing extensive scalding. Grease and oil burns from splashing or spilling hot cooking oil are particularly dangerous because oil reaches higher temperatures than water (frying oil often exceeds 180°C) and adheres to skin, continuing to burn even after initial contact. Flash burns from open flames, though less common in modern kitchens, can occur with gas equipment or flambe preparations.

subsections.heading: 1.1 Contact Burns from Hot Surfaces and Equipment
subsections.content:
Every kitchen contains numerous hot surfaces that present contact burn hazards. Stovetop burners and the areas immediately surrounding them remain hot for extended periods after being turned off. Oven doors, particularly on older ovens without effective insulation, become extremely hot during use. Interior oven racks, baking trays, and roasting pans reach oven temperature (often 200°C+). Pot and pan handles become hot through conduction from the cookware, especially metal handles or handles positioned over adjacent burners. Griddles, grills, and hot plates are designed to maintain high temperatures continuously.

Less obvious hot surfaces include equipment exteriors (commercial ovens, salamanders, warmers, and steam tables often have hot exterior casings), heated serving equipment (chafing dishes, hot cabinets, heat lamps), and cookware recently removed from heat (pots, pans, and utensils retain heat for minutes after removal from burners or ovens). A fundamental safety principle is to assume all equipment and cookware is hot until you have verified otherwise. Never touch kitchen equipment or cookware with bare hands unless you are certain it is cool.

subsections.heading: 1.2 Scald Burns from Hot Liquids and Steam
subsections.content:
Scald burns from hot water, stocks, sauces, soups, and other liquids are extremely common in kitchens. Water boils at 100°C, sufficient to cause severe second-degree burns in less than a second of contact. Many cooking liquids (oil-based sauces, sugar syrups) reach even higher temperatures. Large volumes of hot liquid, such as stockpots of boiling water or soup, present catastrophic injury risk if spilled. Steam, which is water vapor at or above 100°C, is particularly dangerous because it is often invisible (visible 'steam' is actually condensed water droplets; the truly dangerous superheated vapor is invisible), carries enormous thermal energy, and can penetrate through clothing causing severe scalding.

Common scald scenarios include improper draining of pasta or vegetables (tipping boiling water toward yourself rather than away), opening lids or covers that have trapped steam without allowing the steam to vent away from your body, overfilling pots so that liquids boil over onto burners or splash when stirred, collision incidents where workers carrying hot liquids bump into others or are bumped, causing spills, and steam table accidents from reaching across steam or improperly opening steam equipment. Preventing scald burns requires anticipating where steam and hot liquids will go and positioning your body away from these paths.

subsections.heading: 1.3 Oil and Grease Burns
subsections.content:
Frying operations present some of the most severe burn risks in kitchens. Cooking oil in deep fryers or frying pans typically operates at 160-190°C, far above water's boiling point. At these temperatures, oil causes near-instantaneous severe burns on contact. Moreover, oil adheres to skin and clothing, continuing to burn even after initial contact, causing deeper tissue damage than water-based scalds. Oil fires, which can occur if oil is overheated or water contacts hot oil, release additional thermal energy and create flame hazards.

Critical oil safety principles include never overfill fryers or frying pans (oil expands when heated and foams when food is added; overfilling causes spillage), ensure food is as dry as possible before adding to hot oil (water in contact with hot oil causes violent spattering and can trigger oil fires), lower food into hot oil gently using baskets or utensils, never drop or throw food into fryers, maintain safe distance when adding food to hot oil to avoid splatter contact, and never move or attempt to carry hot oil containers (allow to cool first, or use specialized equipment for hot oil transfer). Used cooking oil causes equally severe burns as fresh oil; never assume oil is safe to handle simply because cooking is finished.

sections.heading: 2. Personal Protective Equipment for Burn Prevention
sections.content:
Appropriate PPE is the primary defense against kitchen burns. Unlike cut injuries where technique can largely eliminate risk, many kitchen tasks inherently involve handling hot items, making protective equipment essential rather than optional. Spanish law (Royal Decree 773/1997) requires employers to provide PPE free of charge where risks cannot be eliminated through other means. For kitchen burn hazards, required PPE typically includes heat-resistant gloves or mitts, protective clothing including arm coverage, and for certain high-risk tasks, face and neck protection.

PPE effectiveness depends on proper selection (appropriate for the specific hazard and temperature), correct use (worn when and how intended), good condition (undamaged, clean, properly maintained), and accessibility (readily available at point of use, not stored in inconvenient locations requiring workers to skip using them due to time pressure). Employers must ensure all these conditions are met. Workers must actually use provided PPE and report any deficiencies in fit, condition, or suitability.

subsections.heading: 2.1 Heat-Resistant Gloves and Mitts
subsections.content:
Heat-resistant gloves and oven mitts are designed to provide thermal insulation allowing brief handling of hot items. These PPE items are rated for maximum temperature and duration of contact. Standard kitchen oven mitts typically protect against temperatures up to 200-230°C for brief contact (5-10 seconds). Professional silicone or aramid fiber gloves can withstand higher temperatures (up to 300°C+) and provide better dexterity than bulky mitts. Heat-resistant gloves are essential for handling hot cookware (removing pans from ovens or stovetops), opening oven doors and reaching into ovens, handling baking trays and roasting pans, adjusting oven racks while hot, and moving or positioning hot equipment.

Critical limitations: heat-resistant gloves provide protection for brief contact only, not prolonged handling. Even the best gloves eventually conduct heat through to your hands if you hold a very hot object for extended periods. Wet gloves lose insulating capacity and can even enhance heat transfer through steam generation — never use wet oven mitts or gloves. Damaged gloves with holes or worn areas provide inadequate protection. Check gloves before each use and replace damaged ones immediately. Gloves must be clean; grease or oil contamination can reduce heat resistance and create fire hazards near open flames.

subsections.heading: 2.2 Protective Clothing
subsections.content:
Appropriate clothing provides important burn protection. Chef jackets and kitchen uniforms are traditionally made from heavy cotton or cotton blends because natural fibers char if exposed to flames but do not melt and adhere to skin as synthetic fabrics can. Long sleeves protect forearms from splashes, spatters, and radiant heat from ovens and grills. Full coverage minimizes exposed skin area vulnerable to burns. Kitchen clothing should fit properly — not so loose that it can catch on pot handles or equipment, but not so tight that it restricts movement and makes safe work difficult.

Avoid synthetic fabrics (polyester, nylon, acrylic) in kitchen environments. These materials melt when exposed to heat or flame, adhering to skin and causing severe combination burn and chemical injuries. Even small exposures to flame or very hot surfaces can ignite synthetic fabrics. Prefer natural fibers (cotton, linen) or blends with high natural fiber content. Closed-toe shoes are mandatory in all kitchens; in addition to slip resistance, they provide protection if hot liquids or food are spilled on feet. Some high-risk environments use additional protective clothing such as heat-resistant aprons for frying stations or arm guards for grill work.

subsections.heading: 2.3 Specialized Protection for High-Risk Tasks
subsections.content:
Certain kitchen tasks present such significant burn risks that specialized additional PPE is warranted. High-volume frying operations may justify full-length heat-resistant aprons to protect torso and legs from oil splatter. Grill stations or areas with open flames may use heat-resistant sleeves or arm guards for additional forearm protection beyond jacket sleeves. Face shields can protect against steam or oil splatter for tasks like opening large steamers or working with high-volume fryers. For cleaning tasks involving very hot water or harsh chemicals that can cause chemical burns, specialized gloves combining chemical and thermal protection are appropriate.

When specialized PPE is required, employers must conduct a risk assessment identifying the specific hazard and selecting appropriate protection. Simply providing generic equipment is insufficient; PPE must be matched to the hazard. Workers must receive training in proper use of specialized PPE and understand why it is required. As with all PPE, regular inspection and timely replacement of damaged items is essential. Workers should never feel pressured to work without required PPE due to time constraints or unavailability; if specialized PPE is mandated for a task, the task should not proceed without it.

sections.heading: 3. Safe Work Practices and Procedures
sections.content:
While PPE provides important protection, safe work practices are the foundation of burn prevention. Many kitchen burns result from unsafe behaviors that could be eliminated through proper technique and procedures: reaching across hot surfaces rather than walking around, failing to announce when carrying hot items in shared spaces, opening lids toward rather than away from the body, improper handling of hot oil or splatter-prone cooking operations, and working in a rushed, inattentive manner during high-pressure service periods. Establishing and consistently following safe procedures dramatically reduces burn incidents.

Safe practices must be integrated into standard operating procedures and reinforced through training, supervision, and workplace culture. They should be second nature, performed automatically even under pressure, rather than conscious decisions that might be skipped when time is short. New workers require hands-on training demonstrating safe techniques, supervised practice, and immediate correction of unsafe behaviors. Experienced workers benefit from periodic refreshers and consistent enforcement of procedures.

subsections.heading: 3.1 Safe Handling of Hot Cookware and Equipment
subsections.content:
Always use appropriate heat-resistant gloves or mitts before touching any potentially hot cookware or equipment. Before removing items from ovens, ensure gloves are dry and undamaged. When removing hot pans from ovens, pull the rack out slightly to improve access and reduce reaching into hot oven interior. Lift pans carefully and announce 'hot pan' or similar warning to others nearby. When carrying hot cookware through the kitchen, keep it low and close to your body for better control, announce 'hot behind,' 'caliente,' or clear warnings continuously, walk at normal pace without rushing, and watch for others and obstacles.

When placing hot cookware on surfaces, ensure the destination surface is stable, heat-resistant, and clear of objects. Use trivets or heat pads to protect work surfaces. Turn pot and pan handles inward on stovetops so they cannot be bumped, caught on clothing, or grabbed by children (if applicable). Never leave pot handles extending over adjacent burners where they can become too hot to touch. When adjusting oven racks, wear heat-resistant gloves even if you believe the oven is cool — residual heat can cause burns. If you must reach into or near hot equipment, minimize time in contact and withdraw promptly.

subsections.heading: 3.2 Steam and Lid Management
subsections.content:
Steam causes some of the most severe kitchen burns due to its invisible nature and high thermal energy content. When opening any covered pot, pan, or container that has been heated, always open the lid away from you, tilting the far edge up first so steam vents away from your face and arms. Stand slightly to the side rather than directly over the container. Allow steam to escape completely before reaching into the container. Be especially cautious with pressure cookers, steamers, and other equipment that generates high-pressure steam — follow manufacturer instructions precisely for safe venting before opening.

When draining boiling water from pasta, vegetables, or other foods, position the colander in the sink first, then carefully tip the pot away from you so steam and any splashing water move away from your body. Never drain toward yourself. Use a splash guard if available. When stirring boiling liquids, keep your face and arms back from the pot; splashing boiling liquid can cause severe facial and arm burns. Reduce heat to lower boil intensity if splashing is occurring. If you must bend over cooking liquids to assess them (check color, smell, etc.), turn off heat first and allow surface to calm before bringing your face near.

subsections.heading: 3.3 Frying Safety Procedures
subsections.content:
Deep frying requires meticulous safety discipline due to extreme temperatures and oil fire risk. Before starting frying operations, verify fryer oil level is appropriate (not overfilled), oil temperature is set correctly and monitored (most frying occurs at 160-180°C; temperatures above 190°C risk oil degradation and fire), equipment is stable and not leaking, and heat-resistant gloves and appropriate firefighting equipment (fire blanket, Class F extinguisher) are accessible. Ensure food to be fried is as dry as possible — excess water causes violent spattering when it contacts hot oil.

When adding food to fryers, lower it gently using baskets or long-handled utensils. Never drop or throw food into hot oil. Stand back from the fryer as food enters the oil to avoid splatter. Never overcrowd the fryer, which lowers oil temperature and increases splatter risk. When removing fried food, allow it to drain over the fryer before transferring to holding areas. If oil catches fire, never use water (this causes explosive spread of burning oil); instead, turn off heat if safe to do so, cover with a fire blanket or use a Class F fire extinguisher. If fire is uncontrolled, evacuate and call emergency services. Never attempt to move burning oil.

sections.heading: 4. Kitchen Layout, Equipment, and Maintenance
sections.content:
Burn risks are influenced significantly by kitchen design, equipment selection, and maintenance practices. A well-designed kitchen minimizes burn hazards through thoughtful equipment placement, adequate space for safe workflow, clear designation of hot zones, physical guards on high-temperature equipment, and proper ventilation to remove excess heat and steam. Employers have primary responsibility for these factors, but workers should understand how layout and equipment affect safety and report any hazardous conditions.

Poor kitchen layout exacerbates burn risks: insufficient space between work stations forces workers to reach across hot equipment or carry hot items through congested areas, hot equipment positioned where workers must pass frequently increases collision risk, inadequate workspace around ovens and stovetops makes safe handling difficult, and mixing hot and cold zones without clear demarcation creates situations where workers inadvertently contact hot surfaces. Regular equipment maintenance is equally critical; malfunctioning temperature controls can lead to unexpected extreme heat, damaged door seals allow heat escape, deteriorating insulation makes equipment exteriors hotter than intended, and gas leaks can create flame hazards.

subsections.heading: 4.1 Equipment Selection and Guards
subsections.content:
Modern commercial kitchen equipment incorporates safety features that reduce burn risks. Insulated oven doors maintain exterior temperatures at safer levels. Equipment with 'cool touch' handles and surfaces uses thermal insulation to prevent handles becoming too hot during operation. Temperature limit controls prevent equipment from exceeding safe maximum temperatures. Automatic shutoff features stop heating if equipment malfunctions. When purchasing or replacing equipment, prioritize safety features alongside functional requirements.

Physical guards and barriers provide additional protection. Hood systems over stovetops and grills should be properly sized and positioned to capture heat and steam effectively. Splash guards around frying stations contain oil splatter. Proper spacing between burners allows safe access to each cooking surface without reaching across others. Equipment should be positioned to eliminate need for workers to reach across hot surfaces to access frequently used items. If layout requires reaching across heat sources, employers should install physical barriers (guards, shields) or relocate items to eliminate the hazard.

subsections.heading: 4.2 Preventive Maintenance Programs
subsections.content:
Regular equipment maintenance prevents burn hazards from developing. Maintenance programs should include scheduled professional inspection and servicing of all heat-producing equipment (ovens, fryers, stovetops, grills, steamers), calibration of temperature controls to ensure accurate readings and proper regulation, inspection and replacement of deteriorating insulation, door seals, and gaskets, verification that safety features (automatic shutoffs, temperature limits) are functioning, and cleaning to prevent grease buildup that can ignite. Maintenance records should be kept and available for labor inspection.

Workers should conduct pre-shift equipment checks identifying any obvious damage, unusual odors (burning, gas), irregular heating (equipment hotter than expected, cold spots), malfunctioning controls (settings not matching actual temperatures), and visible damage to insulation or seals. Any equipment showing signs of malfunction should be taken out of service immediately and reported for repair. Never attempt to use malfunctioning heat-producing equipment; unpredictable behavior creates severe burn and fire risks. Management must support workers' authority to take unsafe equipment out of service without pressure to 'make do' until repairs can be scheduled.

subsections.heading: 4.3 Workplace Organization and Cleanliness
subsections.content:
Clutter and poor organization increase burn risks. Overcrowded work surfaces force workers to place hot items in unstable positions where they may tip or be knocked over. Items stored too close to heat sources can become unexpectedly hot. Floors contaminated with grease or spills create slip hazards that are especially dangerous when workers are carrying hot liquids. Maintain clear, organized work areas with designated heat-safe zones for hot cookware, adequate spacing between items to prevent accidental contact, regular cleaning to remove grease and spills, and clear traffic paths through the kitchen.

Use appropriate heat-resistant surfaces (trivets, heat pads, stainless steel surfaces rated for hot cookware) for placing hot items. Never place hot cookware directly on wood, plastic, or other non-heat-resistant surfaces. Color-code or clearly mark heat-safe zones so all workers understand where hot items should be placed. Implement 'clean as you go' practices to prevent accumulation of clutter and spills. During high-volume service periods when kitchens become hectic, maintaining organization becomes more difficult but also more important — chaos increases injury risk significantly.

sections.heading: 5. Communication and Team Coordination
sections.content:
Many kitchen burns involve collisions or proximity incidents in shared kitchen spaces: workers carrying hot pans bump into others, someone reaches for equipment just as another person removes a hot tray, or workers inadvertently pass behind someone working at a hot station without announcing themselves. These incidents are preventable through clear, consistent communication protocols and awareness of others' positions and activities. Kitchen culture should normalize constant verbal communication about movements, particularly when carrying or handling hot items.

Effective kitchen communication requires established standard calls that all workers understand and use consistently. These calls should be short, loud enough to be heard over kitchen noise, and contain specific information about the nature of the hazard. Beyond verbal calls, visual awareness is essential: workers should scan their path before moving, make eye contact with others when necessary, and avoid sudden unexpected movements in shared spaces. Experienced kitchen workers develop almost unconscious spatial awareness of colleagues' positions and likely movements; this skill should be explicitly taught to new workers rather than assumed.

subsections.heading: 5.1 Standard Verbal Calls and Warnings
subsections.content:
Establish and train all workers in standard verbal calls. 'Behind' or 'behind you' warns someone you are passing behind them (they should not step backward or turn suddenly). 'Hot behind' or 'caliente' specifies that you are carrying something hot. 'Sharp behind' warns of carrying knives. 'Coming through' announces movement through a busy area. 'Hot pan' or 'hot tray' specifies the item being carried. 'Oven opening' or 'door' warns nearby workers that oven door will open into shared space. 'Steam' warns of steam release that may affect nearby workers.

These calls should be given loudly, clearly, and proactively — announce before moving, not during or after. In noisy kitchen environments during busy service, calls must be loud enough to be heard over equipment noise, ventilation systems, and general activity. Workers who do not acknowledge your call may not have heard it; repeat until you get acknowledgment or visual confirmation they are aware of your presence. Do not assume that because you called, others definitely heard you. Making these calls should become automatic habit, performed every time without conscious decision.

subsections.heading: 5.2 Traffic Patterns and Flow Management
subsections.content:
Well-designed kitchens establish clear traffic patterns minimizing collisions. Designate 'hot zones' around ovens, stovetops, and fryers where others should not linger unnecessarily. Create one-way flow patterns where possible to prevent head-on collisions in narrow spaces. Position frequently-accessed items (refrigerators, dry storage, dishwashing areas) away from hot cooking zones to avoid unnecessary traffic through high-risk areas. During high-volume service, consider designating 'runners' responsible for carrying items between stations, reducing overall traffic.

Workers should internalize traffic patterns and minimize time spent in hot zones when not directly working there. When passing through hot zones, move deliberately and predictably, watch for others working at hot equipment, announce your passage, and give working chefs maximum space. Never rush through hot zones; the few seconds saved are not worth the burn injury risk from collision. If kitchen layout forces frequent traffic through hot zones, management should redesign workflow to reduce this requirement or install additional protective measures.

subsections.heading: 5.3 Team Coordination During Service
subsections.content:
High-pressure service periods are when burns most frequently occur. Multiple workers are moving quickly, equipment is maximally loaded and hot, attention is divided among many simultaneous tasks, and time pressure creates temptation to skip safety steps. Preventing burns during service requires team discipline: maintain standard verbal calls even when busy, resist the temptation to rush (rushing causes mistakes and injuries that slow service more than a few seconds of caution), brief timeout if the kitchen becomes chaotic beyond safe management, support colleagues by watching their backs (if you see someone about to back into a hot surface, warn them), and debrief after service about any near-misses or safety concerns.

Head chefs and kitchen managers have special responsibility during service to monitor safety, intervene if unsafe practices are occurring, and maintain an overall safe pace even under time pressure. Workers must feel empowered to work safely rather than pressured to cut corners. Creating a culture where safety is never compromised for speed requires consistent leadership messaging and modeling from management. Celebrating safe service periods (e.g., 'busy Saturday night with zero injuries, well done team') reinforces positive practices.

sections.heading: 6. Emergency Response and Burn First Aid
sections.content:
Despite best prevention efforts, burns occasionally occur. Immediate proper first aid can significantly reduce injury severity and long-term consequences. Every kitchen worker should know basic burn first aid principles, the location of first aid supplies including access to cool running water, who the designated first aider is and how to contact them, when burns require professional medical attention, and how to report workplace burn injuries. Kitchen supervisors and managers have additional responsibilities to ensure injured workers receive appropriate care and to investigate incidents.

Burn first aid is time-critical — the first few minutes after a burn determine whether it remains minor or progresses to more severe injury. Heat continues to damage tissue after initial contact until the area is cooled. Early cooling can prevent a borderline first-degree burn from progressing to second-degree, or a superficial second-degree burn from deepening to a severe second-degree burn. Therefore, immediate access to cool running water and knowledge of proper cooling technique are essential in every kitchen.

subsections.heading: 6.1 Immediate First Aid for Burns
subsections.content:
For any burn, immediately cool the affected area under cool (not ice-cold) running water for at least 10-20 minutes. The cooling duration is critical — studies show that inadequate cooling duration is a major factor in burn progression. Cool water should be approximately 15-25°C (tap water is usually suitable; do not use ice or ice water, which can cause additional tissue damage). Continue cooling until pain significantly reduces. For burns involving hot liquids or oil, remove affected clothing while cooling (unless clothing is stuck to the burn, in which case leave it and seek medical attention). Remove jewelry and tight items near the burn area before swelling develops.

After adequate cooling, cover the burn loosely with a clean, dry non-adhesive dressing or clean cloth. Do not apply ice, butter, oil, ointments, or traditional remedies (these do not help and may worsen injury or cause infection). Do not break blisters (this increases infection risk). For very minor first-degree burns (small area, minimal pain after cooling), the above first aid may be sufficient. For larger or more serious burns, seek medical attention after initial cooling. If the burn is severe, begin cooling immediately while summoning emergency help — do not delay cooling to wait for medical assistance.

subsections.heading: 6.2 When to Seek Medical Attention
subsections.content:
Seek immediate professional medical attention for burns that are larger than the palm of the person's hand, involve face, hands, feet, genitals, or major joints, are third-degree (skin appears white, charred, or leathery regardless of size), cause severe pain not controlled by cooling and over-the-counter pain relief, result from chemicals or electrical sources, involve children or elderly individuals with greater vulnerability, or show signs of infection (increasing redness, swelling, pus, fever) in following days.

Also seek medical evaluation for second-degree burns (blistering) if they are larger than a few centimeters, very painful, or if you are uncertain about severity. Medical professionals can assess depth accurately, provide appropriate wound care and dressings, prescribe antibiotics if infection risk is high, administer tetanus prophylaxis if needed, and arrange follow-up care for severe burns. Do not underestimate burn severity — serious burns may initially seem less severe than they are. When in doubt, seek medical assessment.

subsections.heading: 6.3 Reporting and Investigation
subsections.content:
All workplace burns must be reported to the supervisor or employer regardless of severity. This ensures the injury is documented, allows investigation to prevent recurrence, and fulfills legal requirements. For burns requiring medical treatment or causing work absence, the employer must report to Social Security within legal timeframes. Serious burns may require reporting to labor authorities. After any burn injury, the employer should investigate to identify root causes: what was the source of the burn? Was appropriate PPE available and being used? Was the worker using safe technique? Was equipment functioning properly? Were there time pressures or other factors that contributed? Investigation should focus on systemic improvements, not individual blame.

Common investigation findings after burn incidents include inadequate heat-resistant gloves (wrong type, damaged, not available when needed), unsafe work practices (rushing, reaching across hot surfaces, failing to announce hot items), equipment malfunctions (overheating, inadequate guards, poor maintenance), and poor kitchen organization (cluttered work areas, inadequate spacing). Each finding should lead to specific corrective actions. If the same type of burn occurs repeatedly, this indicates systematic failures requiring comprehensive intervention, not just individual worker correction.

checklists.title: Daily Burn Prevention Checklist
items: Verify heat-resistant gloves/mitts are available, clean, dry, and undamaged before starting shift
Conduct pre-shift equipment inspection: check for damage, unusual heating, malfunctioning controls
Verify first aid kit is stocked and accessible, cool running water is available
Review kitchen layout: confirm clear traffic paths, heat-safe zones for hot cookware
Put on appropriate protective clothing: long sleeves, closed-toe slip-resistant shoes, natural fiber fabrics
Before handling any equipment or cookware, verify whether it is hot or cool
Use heat-resistant gloves for all hot item handling
Turn all pot and pan handles inward on stovetops
Announce when carrying hot items: 'hot behind,' 'caliente,' continuous warnings
Open all lids away from you to vent steam safely
Maintain clean, organized work area free of clutter and spills
Report any equipment malfunctions or unsafe conditions immediately

checklists.title: High-Risk Task Safety Checklist (Frying, Grilling, Oven Work)
items: Verify appropriate heat-resistant PPE is worn before beginning task
Check equipment is functioning properly with accurate temperature control
Ensure adequate space around work area for safe handling of hot items
For frying: verify oil level is appropriate, not overfilled; ensure food is dry before adding to oil
For oven work: use dry, undamaged heat-resistant gloves; pull racks out for better access
For grilling: maintain safe distance from open flame; use long-handled utensils
Announce to nearby workers when beginning high-heat operations
Lower food into fryers gently using baskets or tongs; never drop or throw
Allow adequate cooling time before moving or cleaning equipment
Have fire suppression equipment (fire blanket, Class F extinguisher) readily accessible
Maintain focus and avoid distractions during high-heat operations
If equipment behaves unpredictably (unexpected extreme heat, unusual sounds), stop and report immediately

checklists.title: Burn Injury Response Checklist
items: Immediately move away from heat source; alert others to the injury
Begin cooling burn under cool running water (15-25°C) immediately
Continue cooling for at least 10-20 minutes; do not stop early
While cooling, remove clothing and jewelry near burn area (unless stuck to skin)
After adequate cooling, cover burn with clean, dry non-adhesive dressing
Do not apply ice, butter, ointments, or break blisters
Assess burn severity: first-degree (redness only), second-degree (blistering), third-degree (white/charred skin)
For burns larger than palm, involving face/hands/feet, or third-degree, seek immediate medical attention after initial cooling
Report injury to supervisor immediately regardless of severity
For serious burns, summon emergency services (112) and continue cooling until help arrives
Document how the injury occurred for investigation
Cooperate with employer's incident investigation to identify causes and prevent recurrence

bestPractices: Develop reflexive habits: always assume equipment is hot until verified cool; always use heat-resistant gloves for potential hot items
Vocalize continuously when carrying hot items through shared kitchen space; do not assume others see you
Create a personal pre-shift safety routine: inspect gloves, verify first aid location, check equipment, prepare work area
During busy service, maintain safety discipline even under time pressure; rushing causes injuries that slow service more than caution would
After any burn or near-miss, take a moment to analyze what happened and what preventive measure could help next time
Support team safety culture: if you see unsafe practices by colleagues, address supportively or report to supervisor
Keep work area organized and clutter-free throughout shift, not just at start; clean as you go
If you feel rushed or overwhelmed to the point safety is compromised, communicate this to supervisor; staffing or workflow changes may be needed

glossary.Quemadura de Primer Grado: First-degree burn — affects only outer skin layer; causes redness and pain but heals without scarring
glossary.Quemadura de Segundo Grado: Second-degree burn — extends into deeper skin layer; causes blistering, severe pain, may scar
glossary.Quemadura de Tercer Grado: Third-degree burn — destroys full skin thickness; appears white or charred; requires immediate medical attention
glossary.Guante Resistente al Calor: Heat-resistant glove — protective glove providing thermal insulation for handling hot items
glossary.Escaldadura: Scald — burn caused by hot liquid or steam
glossary.Salpicadura de Aceite: Oil splatter — droplets of hot cooking oil that can cause burns
glossary.Vapor: Steam — water vapor at or above 100°C; can cause severe invisible scald burns
glossary.Quemadura por Contacto: Contact burn — burn caused by touching hot surfaces or equipment
glossary.Enfriamiento: Cooling — first aid technique of running cool water over burn to reduce tissue damage
glossary.Equipo de Protección Individual (EPI): Personal protective equipment (PPE) — safety equipment including heat-resistant gloves and protective clothing
